Another common term is working day. Typically, these are the days between and including Monday to Friday and do not include public holidays and weekends. The definition of a business day varies by region. It depends on the local work week which is dictated by local customs, religions, and business operations. For example, in the United States and much of the Western world, they are typically Monday to Friday. Within a few gulf countries the normal business days are Sunday to Thursday.</xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:sequence> <xs:element name="Day" type="ns51:DayType"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation>A day is a unit of time. Each day of the week is named in different languages after classical planets, various deities. Product Offering may represent a simple offering of a single Product Specification or could represent a bundling of one or more other Product Offering.</xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexContent> <xs:extension base="ns51:BaseComponentType"/> </xs:complexContent> </xs:complexType> <xs:complexType name="PublicEntityType"> <xs:sequence> <xs:element name="DomesticUltimateBusinessName" type="cct:TextType" minOccurs="0"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation>The primary DUNS number of the organisation in its domestic market.</xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="DUNSNumbers" type="ns51:DUNSNumberType" minOccurs="0"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation>The primary DUNS number for an organisation.</xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="NumberOfEmployees" type="ns51:NumberOfEmployeesType" minOccurs="0"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation>The total number of employees in the organisation.</xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> <xs:element name="OtherRegisterNumber" type="cct:IDType" minOccurs="0"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation>An alternative registration number for the organisation.</xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:element> </xs:sequence> <xs:attribute name="actionCode" type="ns51:ActionCodeType"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation>The @actionCode attribute is used within a modification operation to indicate the action (add, update, delete) intended on a component.</xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> </xs:attribute> </xs:complexType> <xs:complexType name="PublicHolidayType"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation>A public holiday, national holiday or legal holiday is a holiday generally established by law and is usually a non-working day during the year. the SalesAccount. A sales account is a representation of a potential customer (prospect) around which sales activity is focused.</xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexContent> <xs:extension base="ns51:BaseComponentType"/> </xs:complexContent> </xs:complexType> <xs:complexType name="SalesLeadReferenceType"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation>A lead is the identification of an individual or organisation (Party) that has the interest and authority to purchase a product or service. This represents the first stage of a sales process. The identification of the lead is referred to as Lead Generation, a process conducted by either the marketing or sales organization. Thus, the Lead Entity in CIM is generated by the Lead Generation Interaction. This is a Party Interaction. The lead may have an organisation associated ( an Enterprise Sales Lead) with the individual(s). For potential Enterprise Customers, The lead is considered to be a role of Organisation since the Lead individual will not become a customer per se. The individual represents the company (Legal Entity) with which Vodafone hope to do business.</xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexContent> <xs:extension base="ns51:BaseComponentType"/> </xs:complexContent> </xs:complexType> <xs:complexType name="SalesOpportunityReferenceType"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation>An Opportunity is an opportunity to generate revenue from the account or lead. Opportunities are the pending deals that need to be tracked. Opportunities build the pipeline, which will contribute to the forecast.</xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexContent> <xs:extension base="ns51:BaseComponentType"/> </xs:complexContent> </xs:complexType> <xs:complexType name="SalesOrderReferenceType"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation>A Sales Order that was created from a Quote.</xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexContent> <xs:extension base="ns51:BaseComponentType"/> </xs:complexContent> </xs:complexType> <xs:complexType name="SalesPartnerAccountReferenceType"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation>A type definition for the sales partner account. Sales Partner Account is a special type of Partner Account that is used to manage the relationship with and activity of a Sales Partner</xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexContent> <xs:extension base="ns51:BaseComponentType"/> </xs:complexContent> </xs:complexType> <xs:complexType name="SolutionOfferingReferenceType"> <xs:annotation> <xs:documentation>Especially for Enterprise Customers, the product offering that forms the basis of the Quote will be customised for a specific customer. This Customised Offering is not the same as a Product although the final 'accepted' customised offering will be the specification for the product build. Customised Offerings may go through multiple versions before being accepted.</xs:documentation> </xs:annotation> <xs:complexContent> <xs:extension base="ns51:BaseComponentType"/> </xs:complexContent> The result of the calculation is the proportion in percent of, e.g., amounts, values, rates, discounts, and taxes.
